snippet: Families displaced 47 years ago worry that they will not be able to afford housing in a new development being built on the site of their old tenements.
abstract: Side Street column holds that decades-long effort to rebuild five blocks on Delancey Street on Manhattan's Lower East Side will result in the rebuilding of a neighborhood, but not of a community; some 1,800 families, mostly poor and Puerto Rican, were uprooted 47 years ago, their tenement homes demolished in the name of urban renewal; affordable housing advocates fear that new housing will not ensure that those displaced so long ago will have a chance to rent the new apartments.
lead_paragraph: Families displaced 47 years ago worry that they will not be able to afford housing in a new development being built on the site of their old tenements.

headline.main: Rebuilding a Neighborhood, but Not a Community
headline.print_headline: Rebuilding a Neighborhood, but Not a Community
